info.author: Ian Flitman
info.title: Jane
info.description: Jane is a dialogue-based narrative network for two actors. Jake and John talk about their wives and a woman they share called Jane. They have six conversations that are divided into three sections each. The dialogue is written with numerous line alternatives throughout. All line combinations are equally valid creating differing portraits of the men and the figure of Jane.

section.summary: John makes up different endings to the film he watched.

option.line: We found a solution to that. We became mutual parasites. That way if one of you leaves, you both die.
option.name: mutual_parasites

option.line: I remember first thinking about Jane when I was three.
option.name: when_three

option.line: Not a prison of old ones.
option.name: old_prison

option.line: Sexual convenience comes at a price.
option.name: convenience

option.line: Or loving the fact that you hate her so much.
option.name: love_hate

option.line: Marriage is an act of faith, the hardest of spirtual disciplines.
option.name: spritual_discipline

option.line: We can forgive a pretty face almost anything.
option.name: pretty_face

option.line: A decent pair of buttocks are not hard to find, John.
option.name: buttocks

option.line: Meet the mother. If you can imagine doing it with her, you're made for life.
option.name: meet_mother

section.summary: They talk about the kind of stories that Jane tells.

option.line: Jane. Her fantasy is quite extraordinary.
Jane. Her fantasy is hard to duplicate.
Jane. Her fantasy begins on the edge of terror.
There's no one like Jane.
There's a bit of Jane in all of us.
Her stories never really end. You know, in a tidy little knot at the end.
They contradict themselves like dreams.
The most innocent and the most cruel.
They round and round in circles. Like we all do.
They splinter like remote controlled TV.
She has no need of stories herself. She creates them wherever she goes.
Greek myths meet science fiction. Men as the heroic and redundant species.
Her storybook is her own version of history.
Her eyes get glazed over. Their focus not even within but totally elsewhere.
Her eyes get glazed over. Fixed like a totem. Commanding and indifferent.
Her eyes get glazed over as she sees all the stories at once.
Her eyes get glazed over. A self-inflicted wound she cures with language.
Her eyes get glazed over and her pupils shrink to a full stop.
Her eyes get glazed over and you vanish in the impersonal stare.
Her eyes get glazed over when the narrative narcotic kicks in.
I get mesmerised by the movement of her lips.
I get mesmerised by the cadence falling from her lips.
Her voice is the sound of a litany.
Her voice is how a woman should really sound.
But her kiss is cold like Judas.
And her kiss haunts you. Like ecstasy.
Red waves undulating over vowels. Teeth biting on consonants.
I forget what she is saying and yet I understand.
The only thing language can do is surrender.
And she can scream like a Banshee.
Amen. And when you respond you respond on behalf of all men.
A voice you and close to eyes to and listen.
A mother talking beautifully to her child.
And she sleeps with her eyes wide open.
A delicious kiss that bends you into submission.
And you whole life beomes a kind of purgatory towards another moment like that.
But her affections are quite the carnivore. They feed on your worship.
No, it's her hands. When she touches me I get so happy inside.
No, it's her hands. Those graceful ambassadors to her state.
I remember all that she said and yet I never understand.
Sometimes I wish I could forget some of the things she has said.
Sometimes it falls like sweet rain, sometimes like a plague of curses.
And then take no prisoners.

section.summary: John talks about the dream life he would like to lead.

cut.speaker: Jake
cut.line: What is your fantasy? The thing you dream about when your eyes are wide open?

option.line: To be a name on other people's lips.

section.summary: John has an argument with his wife.

cut.line: Is your wife still doing it?
cut.name: still doing it

option.line: I forgot to put the toilet seat down. It drives her wild.

option.line: Jill thinks I'm having an affair.
option.name: thinks affair

option.line: I told her I didn't want to sleep with her anymore.
option.name: not sleep with her

option.line: Jill has low self-esteem. Attacking someone helps.

option.line: She's got to do something to fill the childless vacuum.

option.line: I went straight to Jane and cried in her lap.

option.line: Deep down I know it's for my own good.

option.line: That's just the trouble. She was all delicious afterward.

option.line: That's just the trouble. She was. Then I have to console her.
option.name: console her

option.line: That's just the trouble. She was. Then I have to forgive her.
option.name: have to forgive

option.line: That's just the trouble. Sorry isn't in her vocabulary.

option.line: That's just the trouble. Don't worry. I made sure she was.

option.line: That's just the trouble. She doesn't need to. I enjoy the strife.

option.line: Buy her some flowers for Christ sake.
option.name: buy flowers

option.line: Go and see Jane, she will tell you what to do.
option.name: see Jane

option.line: Jane would never do a thing like that.
option.name: Jane never do

option.line: Jane is a lot worse in many ways.
option.name: Jane worse

option.name: functional relationship

option.line: No need. She's grown allergic to such gestures.
option.name: allergic to gestures

option.line: Jane doesn't care about my life. Why should she?
option.name: no care for life

option.line: Jane doesn't care about my wife. Why should she?
option.name: no care for wife

option.line: And then face her when I haven't done it? No, thank you.
option.name: face her

option.line: And that's why we love her so. Isn't it, Jake?
option.name: why we love her

option.line: Jane is capable of anything. You should know that.
option.name: capable of anything

option.line: And a lot lot better too.

option.line: That's why she needs the pair of us. To share the load.
option.name: share the load

option.line: I know.
option.name: i know

option.line: Please. No need for that sort of thing. We have a functional relationship.
option.name: functional Jake

option.line: Now don't you get all homosexual, Jake.

section.summary: John resolves to work things out with his wife.

option.line: Tonight I will procure myself a remedy.
option.name: procure a remedy

option.line: Tonight it will end.
option.name: end tonight

default.line: I've dirtied my underpants in self-defence.
default.name: underpants

option.line: My wife must learn what disgust really means.
option.name: must learn disgust

option.line: Skid marks from a grown man will make her feel like a mother.
option.name: skid marks

default.line: I'll bring out the wedding photos again.

option.line: And this time her conscience will be the thing that gets pricked.

option.line: Nothing like the glow of past happiness to put things in perspective.

default.line: I'm going to do my best to flirt with her without shame.

option.line: I will tell her every little lie she wants to hear.

option.line: Confound them with kindness that's what I say.

option.name: Jake mimics John

option.line: I know you don't like to hear it.
option.name: don't like to hear

option.line: What's that? You're getting just like the wife.

option.line: It's not going to happen tonight or any other night.
option.name: not going to happen

option.line: Your life is in permanent deja vu.

option.line: You little squirt.

section.summary: While John is jealous of Jake's married life, Jake is not so sure why.

cut.speaker: John
cut.line: What is your fantasy? The thing you dream about when your eyes are wide open?

option.line: That my wife and Jane become lovers.
That I could tell my wife about Jane.
That I could leave my wife.
That I could marry Jane.
That I could leave Jane.
That's a nightmare, brother.
Don't you see it will never end?
A bit of psychic suicide never did anyone any harm.
I worry about you sometimes, do you know that?
Jane doesn't even like women. They mean nothing to her.
Still, masturbation and a deathwish. How exciting.
They might fall in love and then totally reject me.
She wouldn't understand Jane at all.
Jane knows all about her. She says she only needs to look at me.
I wouldn't know how to begin or where.
Without her, Jane would disappear.
Without her, I would probably disappear.
Find someone else to point myself at.
So I could walk again this Earth a predator after sex.
Just my luck. The only one who truly makes me happy and she's not the marrying kind.
Just our luck. The only one who truly makes us happy and she's not the marrying kind.
Makes you wonder how long I would last.
Sweet annihilation and the perfect death.

default.line: Jane would find me anyway. She's like that.

option.line: Vindictive.
Sticky.
Magical.
Uninvited.
All adjectives lie before the name of Jane.
Imagine sleeping with the pair of them.
Imagine sleeping with the pair of us.
You, my wife and Jane. How's that for size?
You, your wife and Jane. How's that for size?
You, my wife and me. How's that for size?
You, your wife and me. How's that for size?
You, me and Jane. How's that for size?
My head would explode.
My heart would explode.
My penis would explode.
My soul would explode.
My sense of shame would implode.
My sense of self would implode.

section.summary: Jane, her gay entourage and Jake's sexuality.

cut.speaker: John
cut.line: Anyhow, you're a lucky man. Tonight you go home to the wife you love.

option.line: What's love got to do with it?
Whatever love means.
It's not like I've got any choice anymore.
Believe me when I look in the mirror I get jealous.
Imagine living with the person you would die for.
There is no greater privilege.
In the name of love, I find you will put up with almost anything.
Far far too much.
Far far too little.
Suicide or sacrifice. Take your pick.
In the name of love, I find you will put up with almost anything.
Far far too much.
Far far too little.
Suicide or sacrifice. Take your pick.
The definition of middle age.
Nothing more frightening than a real decision though, Jake. Nothing.
You can but choose from what little there is on offer.
When I look in the mirror, I see the mistakes I have made.
When I look in the mirror, it's love at first sight all over again.
When I look in the mirror, I see myself as others see me.
Imagine living with the person you have already died for.
No, I can't really imagine living on my own. Can you?
To be constantly at someone else's convenience.
And that's what makes it so bloody sad.
Or alas responsibility.
And every day we say I do.
Sometimes I wish I was gay.
Sometimes I wish I was asexual.
Sometimes I wish I was bisexual.
Maybe that would settle it all.
And take the next evolutionary step.
Not in a million years.
Maybe I could still see Jane.
Yes, you're right. I love my wife.
Jane has a lot of gay friends. Do you think they were once all straight?

section.summary: Jake seeks a solution to his double life with Jane and his wife.

cut.speaker: John
cut.line: Jane was with her homosexual chums last night. I could hear them in the background.

option.line: A bunch of queens at court where Jane is Queen of Sheba.
Discussing who was going to impregnate her. And how.
Squelching and a felching me thinks.
Imagine doing what they do, Jake. Just imagine it.
Arguing among themselves who loved Jane most of all.
Arguing among themselves who understood Jane most of all.

default.line: Discussing who was the sexiest straight man Jane knew.

option.line: Sadly neither you nor I.
Happily neither you nor I.
(looking hopefully at John) How many were there?
(emits a contemptuous sound) How many were there?
(looks guiltily at John as if he was there) How many were there?
(mimes 'I love you' at John) How many were there?
I bet they don't have it easy with her either.
I bet they get along just fine. No sexual friction, see.
It's one on one when I'm with her.
My wife can't stand them.
They fear Jane too. Secretly secretly.
They hate her too. Secretly secretly.
Like we all do.
And she of course loves it.
Jane makes them wish they were straight.
Jane makes them see their mothers in a new and estranged light.
They are her naughty priests.
They know Jane can have any man she wants.
Jane is beyond sexual orientation.
She is the Mistress complex incarnate.
Jane told me I'm a gay mind trapped inside a straight man's body.
Jane told me I'm a straight mind trapped inside a gay man's body.
Jane told me I'm a straight man trapped inside a straight man's body.
Jane told me I'm a straight woman trapped inside a straight man's body.
Jane told me I'm a woman's mind trapped inside a man's body.
Jane told me I'm a child's mind trapped inside a man's body.
Jane told me I'm a lesbian trapped inside a straight man's body.
And she was my only escape.
A common enough ailment she has found.
A blessing of sorts or an inflexible curse I cannot tell.
And then she raped me.
Only I didn't want to know it.
That's why my mother hated me so much.
It's the cross I have to bear. Crucifixion guaranteed.

section.summary: Jake has dinner cooked for him again tonight.

cut.speaker: Jake
cut.line: Do you know what tonight is?

option.line: (thinks) Monday night.
(thinks) Tuesday night.
(thinks) Wednesday night.
(thinks) Thursday night.
(thinks) Friday night.
(thinks) Saturday night.
(thinks) Sunday night.

default.line: I asked you that just before.

option.line: Getting senile or what?
Get your own opening gambit. Copy cat.
You're making me feel all schizoid.
No kidding. Maybe your wife cooks too much.
The daily sacrament of food we observe so badly.
We tried that once. It didn't work.
Personally I'm sick of eating. There's no escape.
That sophisticated and altogether human pursuit of sustenance.
Jill loves me through her food.
Jill controls me through her food.
I love Jill through her food.
I control Jill through her food.
Jill, she likes to look after me.
When she bends down in that apron of hers. Knives all around. It's very tempting.
The way she moves her peachy butt around when she mopes the floor. It's all very tempting.
She puts her hair up when she's in the kitchen. Such an exquisite neck.
When she works the saucepan she offers me her profile. Both face and breast.
When she cooks her mother's recipe her transformation is complete.
There's nothing like a spatula in a woman's hand.
My wife had skin like a banana once. Smooth and inviting. And like a banana it got a bit mottled.
My wife's breast were once my favourite fruit. Now they're attracting flies.
My wife is a dangerously ripe woman. She is saturated with juice.
When the varicose veins first rippled through my wife, her leg became a piece of meat.
Men are so superficial.
Women are so skin deep.
When she starts chopping cucumbers and the like I begin to get nervous.
She can decapitate a bird without a blink of an eye.
Every day I hear her sharpen the knives. Then she puts oil on them so they glisten.
That brisk efficency. Time ticking on a souffle. Coordination amid the boiling waters.
She cooks and I shop. With her handwritten list of delicatessens and remarks to the butcher.
I get table inspection at six twenty-one or so. Plates at twenty hundred hours.
And if I drop a single crumb on a newly hovered floor I'm done for.
I thank her accordingly. I pass comment on the food.
She burns the saucepans, and I have to scrape them clean.
I have to listen to her and she talks through her food like a man.
Children find routine so reassuring.
Routine, the death knell to anything vaguely interesting.
It's never plain sailing with women. Never.
Try sneezing over the food. I find that always helps.

section.summary: John warns Jake about the perils of kitchen politics.

option.line: Life is an inedible fantasy.
Life is a gastronomic fantasy.

cut.speaker: Jake
cut.line: It is. Take my wife. She can cook anything.

option.line: Except fish. Their dead eyes give her nightmares.
Except eggs. She swears she can hear a baby bird scream when she cracks one open.
Except read meat. The smell of it raw reminds her of her father.
Except liver. She's always convinced it is human.
Except with the microwave. She stares at the clock counting down to zero and thinks of death.
Except beef. Her teddy bear was a cow.
Nothing like a woman's weakness to blind you to her power.
Nothing like a woman's weakness to bind you to her power.
Nothing like a woman's weakness to make you feel in control.
I like it when my wife has nightmares. For a few seconds she really needs me again.

cut.speaker: John
cut.line: For me it brings out the matriarch, the kitchen.

option.line: All the best cooks are men, after all.
I tell my wife to steer well clear.
She cooked once and I never forgave her.
We live on bread and cheese and red wine.
And there's no beast on hell or earth quite like that.

default.line: I do all the cooking but my wife keeps touching me up. She cannot leave me alone.

option.line: It's the scent of cooking meat.
She says I'm just too sexy with a knife in my hand.
She's particularly fond of sinking her teeth into my buttocks.
Nice to know that men are just better women than women are.
All the best of anything are men.
I have to tread carefully in the delicate territory of her kitchen.
She won't even let me help, the sweet Cinderella.
If my wife cuts herself and sees her own blood, she gets very confused.

default.line: I cooked once and she never forgave me.

option.line: We are the inverse copies of each other apparently.
Maybe we should wife swap.
If I suggest a takeaway, my wife gets a panic attack.
(happy) She's cooking polenta again.
(frustrated) She's cooking polenta again.
And Jane could be the queen of matriarchs if she wanted to.
Jane eats matriarchs for breakfast.
Men may destroy the Earth, but women give birth to destroyers.
We don't have sex in the kitchen or we'll miss doing it when we have kids.
Be thankful she's still interested. A minor miracle given the state of you. Honestly.
Admit it. You just ooze sex with your clever indifference.

default.line: There's always a backbite of responsibility to the food.

option.line: A favour I must implicitly return.
There is no such thing as a free lunch.

default.line: There's always the spice of guilt to the food.

option.line: A sense of not being worth the trouble she takes.
At the rock bottom ingratitude I know is inside me.
Not that she notices. She just talks about herself all the time.
But when we talk all that disappears until next time.
Thankfully we've learnt to change the subject through the art of conversation.

cut.speaker: John
cut.line: We always have the TV on when we eat. It's simpler.

option.line: They cancel each other out rather well.
They complement each other rather well.
Cookery programmes I find are best.
(linked to 'cancel') The food and the TV.
